en: Ancient olive trees discovered at Spanish EU Cultural Heritage Prize-winning site
The historical landscape of El Sénia’s ancient olive trees won the EU Prize for Cultural Heritage / Europa Nostra Awards back in 2014.
Ancient olive trees discovered at Spanish EU Cultural Heritage Prize-winning site
58-Document for general distribution (intended for the general public)

The historical landscape of El Sénia’s ancient olive trees won the EU Cultural Heritage / Europa Nostra awards back in 2014. On the back of a recent study, the two oldest specimens in El Sénia have been discovered.

On the back of a recent study, the two particularly ancient specimens in El Sénia have been discovered.

  • The olive tree no. 1,878, known as the Forge of Arion is in Ulldecona (Tarragona) has an estimated age of 1701 years, being planted in 314, during the reign of Emperor Constantine I (306-337 AD).

  • The olive tree no. 117, known as the Forge of Pou Mas, located in La Jana (Castellón), has an estimated age of 1182 years and was planted in 833, during the Emirate of Abderramán II (822-852 AD).

The territory of Sénia consists of 27 municipalities (15 from Valencia, 9 from Catalonia and 3 from Aragon) which share the largest concentration of ancient olive trees: some 4700 monumental trees of the Farga variety. These trees produce an oil of special quality.

These two specimens have survived for an amazing length of time and still produce excellent oil.

The trees' ages were discovered in a study commissioned by Group Santander. Many technologies were used for dating the trees over the course of the study and many public organisations active in forestry and woodland research, as well as the Madrid School of Forestry Engineering, participated in the study.

The conservation project at El Sénia aims to protect the ancient forest from various dangers such as citrus farming and uprooting to be used as high-end ornaments elsewhere.

The EU Cultural Heritage Prize / Europa Nostra Awards is supported by the Creative Europe programme.
